chunk:
The following content describes information about software. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: BackConfig
Software description: [BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475) is a custom Trojan with a flexible plugin architecture that has been used by [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040).(Citation: Unit 42 BackConfig May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Prestige
Software description: [Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) ransomware has been used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least March 2022, including against transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland in October 2022.(Citation: Microsoft Prestige ransomware October 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CosmicDuke
Software description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Volgmer
Software description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) is a backdoor Trojan designed to provide covert access to a compromised system. It has been used since at least 2013 to target the government, financial, automotive, and media industries. Its primary delivery mechanism is suspected to be spearphishing. (Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Derusbi
Software description: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is malware used by multiple Chinese APT groups.(Citation: Novetta-Axiom)(Citation: ThreatConnect Anthem) Both Windows and Linux variants have been observed.(Citation: Fidelis Turbo)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: BabyShark
Software description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) is a Microsoft Visual Basic (VB) script-based malware family that is believed to be associated with several North Korean campaigns. (Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Empire
Software description: [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) is an open source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. While the tool itself is primarily written in Python, the post-exploitation agents are written in pure [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) for Windows and Python for Linux/macOS. [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) was one of five tools singled out by a joint report on public hacking tools being widely used by adversaries.(Citation: NCSC Joint Report Public Tools)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire)(Citation: GitHub ATTACK Empire)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CharmPower
Software description: [CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) is a PowerShell-based, modular backdoor that has been used by [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) since at least 2022.(Citation: Check Point APT35 CharmPower January 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Metamorfo
Software description: [Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group that has been active since at least April 2018. The group focuses on targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.(Citation: Medium Metamorfo Apr 2020)(Citation: ESET Casbaneiro Oct 2019) 
Platforms: Windows

Software description: [yty](https

entities.name: COBALT STRIKE
entities.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial, full-featured remote access tool designed for adversary simulation and executing targeted attacks, emulating the actions of advanced threat actors.

entities.name: BACKCONFIG
entities.description: BackConfig is a custom Trojan with a flexible plugin architecture used by Patchwork.

entities.name: PRESTIGE
entities.description: Prestige is a ransomware used by Sandworm Team, targeting transportation and logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland since at least March 2022.

entities.name: COSMICDUKE
entities.description: CosmicDuke is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015.

entities.name: VOLGMER
entities.description: Volgmer is a backdoor Trojan providing covert access to compromised systems, targeting various industries since at least 2013.

entities.name: DERUSBI
entities.description: Derusbi is malware used by multiple Chinese APT groups, with both Windows and Linux variants observed.

entities.name: BABYSHARK
entities.description: BabyShark is a Microsoft Visual Basic script-based malware family associated with several North Korean campaigns.

entities.name: EMPIRE
entities.description: Empire is an open-source, cross-platform remote administration and post-exploitation framework available on GitHub.

entities.name: COMRAT
entities.description: ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected to be a descendant of Agent.btz, used by Turla since its first identification in 2007.

entities.name: CHARMPOWER
entities.description: CharmPower is a PowerShell-based modular backdoor used by Magic Hound since at least 2022.

entities.name: METAMORFO
entities.description: Metamorfo is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico since at least April 2018.

entities.name: SANDWORM TEAM
entities.description: Sandworm Team is a hacking group that has been associated with the use of Prestige ransomware since at least March 2022.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group known for using CosmicDuke malware from 2010 to 2015.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a hacking group that has been linked to the use of ComRAT malware in cyber operations.

entities.name: MAGIC HOUND
entities.description: Magic Hound is a group that has been associated with the use of CharmPower backdoor since at least 2022.

entities.name: BRAZILIAN CYBERCRIME GROUP
entities.description: A Brazilian cybercrime group that operates the Metamorfo banking trojan, targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.

amorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group that has been active since at least April 2018. The group focuses on targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.(Citation: Medium Metamorfo Apr 2020)(Citation: ESET Casbaneiro Oct 2019) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: yty
Software description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) is a modular, plugin-based malware framework. The components of the framework are written in a variety of programming languages. (Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MacMa
Software description: [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) is a macOS-based backdoor with a large set of functionalities to control and exfiltrate files from a compromised computer. [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) has been observed in the wild since November 2021.(Citation: ESET DazzleSpy Jan 2022)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Meteor
Software description: [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is a wiper that was used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, the Ministry of Roads, and Urban Development systems, in July 2021. [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is likely a newer version of similar wipers called Stardust and Comet that were reportedly used by a group called "Indra" since at least 2019 against private companies in Syria.(Citation: Check Point Meteor Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HotCroissant
Software description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed by U.S. government entities to malicious North Korean government cyber activity, tracked collectively as HIDDEN COBRA.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020) [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) shares numerous code similarities with [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433).(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FIVEHANDS
Software description: [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) is a customized version of [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) ransomware written in C++. [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) has been used since at least 2021, including in Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) campaigns, sometimes along with [SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615).(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)(Citation: NCC Group Fivehands June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Avaddon
Software description: [Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) since at least June 2020.(Citation: Awake Security Avaddon)(Citation: Arxiv Avaddon Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Peppy
Software description: [Peppy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0643) is a Python-based remote access Trojan, active since at least 2012, with similarities to [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115).(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PolyglotDuke
Software description: [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) is a downloader that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2013. [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) has been used to drop [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051).(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Daserf
Software description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) is a backdoor that has been used to spy on and steal from Japanese, South Korean, Russian, Singaporean, and Chinese victims. Researchers have identified versions written in both Visual C and Delphi. (Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017) (Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KOMPROGO
Software description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is a signature backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) that is capable of process, file, and registry management. (Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: MarkiRAT
Software description: [MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) compiled with Visual Studio that has been used by [Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) since at least 2015.(Citation: Kaspersky Ferocious Kitten Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUH

entities.name: AMORFO
entities.description: Amorfo is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group that targets banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico since at least April 2018.

entities.name: BRAZIL
entities.description: Brazil is a country in South America where the Amorfo banking trojan is actively targeting banks and cryptocurrency services.

entities.name: MEXICO
entities.description: Mexico is a country in North America that is also targeted by the Amorfo banking trojan.

entities.name: YTY
entities.description: YTY is a modular, plugin-based malware framework with components written in various programming languages.

entities.name: MACMA
entities.description: MacMa is a macOS-based backdoor that has functionalities to control and exfiltrate files from compromised computers, observed since November 2021.

entities.name: METEOR
entities.description: Meteor is a wiper used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, in July 2021, likely a newer version of similar wipers.

entities.name: HOTCROISSANT
entities.description: HotCroissant is a remote access trojan attributed to North Korean government cyber activity, sharing code similarities with Rifdoor.

entities.name: FIVEHANDS
entities.description: FIVEHANDS is a customized version of DEATHRANSOM ransomware used in Ransomware-as-a-Service campaigns since at least 2021.

entities.name: AVADDON
entities.description: Avaddon is ransomware offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service since at least June 2020.

entities.name: PEPPY
entities.description: Peppy is a Python-based remote access Trojan active since at least 2012, with similarities to Crimson.

entities.name: POLYGLOTDUKE
entities.description: PolyglotDuke is a downloader used by APT29 since at least 2013 to drop MiniDuke.

entities.name: DASERF
entities.description: Daserf is a backdoor used to spy on and steal from victims in multiple countries including Japan, South Korea, and China.

entities.name: KOMPROGO
entities.description: KOMPROGO is a signature backdoor used by APT32 capable of process, file, and registry management.

entities.name: MARKIRAT
entities.description: MarkiRAT is a remote access Trojan used by Ferocious Kitten since at least 2015.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that many malware, including YTY and HotCroissant, are designed to operate on.

entities.name: RANSOMWARE
entities.description: Ransomware refers to a type of malicious software that encrypts files and demands payment for their release, including variants like FIVEHANDS and Avaddon.

entities.name: APT32
entities.description: APT32 is a cyber espionage group that uses KOMPROGO as a backdoor for its operations.

entities.name: FEROCIOUS KITTEN
entities.description: Ferocious Kitten is a cybercriminal group that has been linked to the use of MarkiRAT malware.

entities.name: INDRA
entities.description: Indra is a group that has reportedly used wipers like Meteor against private companies in Syria since at least 2019.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that MacMa operates on, designed for Apple computers.

entities.name: CYBERCRIME
entities.description: Cybercrime encompasses illegal activities conducted via the internet, including the operations of groups like Amorfo and their banking trojans.)<|COMPLETE|>

2021.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="METEOR">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Meteor is a wiper used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, in July 2021, likely a newer version of similar wipers.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="HOTCROISSANT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">HotCroissant is a remote access trojan attributed to North Korean government cyber activity, sharing code similarities with Rifdoor.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="FIVEHANDS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">FIVEHANDS is a customized version of DEATHRANSOM ransomware used in Ransomware-as-a-Service campaigns since at least 2021.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="AVADDON">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Avaddon is ransomware offered as Ransomware-as-a-Service since at least June 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="PEPPY">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Peppy is a Python-based remote access Trojan active since at least 2012, with similarities to Crimson.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="POLYGLOTDUKE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">PolyglotDuke is a downloader used by APT29 since at least 2013 to drop MiniDuke.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="DASERF">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Daserf is a backdoor used to spy on and steal from victims in multiple countries including Japan, South Korea, and China.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="KOMPROGO">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">KOMPROGO is a signature backdoor used by APT32 capable of process, file, and registry management.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="MARKIRAT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">MarkiRAT is a remote access Trojan used by Ferocious Kitten since at least 2015.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="WINDOWS">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Windows is an operating system platform that many malware, including YTY and HotCroissant, are designed to operate on.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>      <data key="d3">GEO</data>    </node>    <node id="IRAN">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="NORTH KOREA">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="RANSOMWARE">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Ransomware refers to a type of malicious software that encrypts files and demands payment for their release, including variants like FIVEHANDS and Avaddon.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>      <data key="d3">EVENT</data>    </node>    <node id="APT29">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="MULTIPLE COUNTRIES">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="APT32">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">APT32 is a cyber espionage group that uses KOMPROGO as a backdoor for its operations.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>      <data key="d3">ORGANIZATION</data>    </node>    <node id="FEROCIOUS KITTEN">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1">Ferocious Kitten is a cybercriminal group that has been linked to the use of MarkiRAT malware.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>      <data key="d3">ORGANIZATION</data>    </node>    <node id="INDRA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Indra is a group that has reportedly used wipers like Meteor against private companies in Syria since at least 2019.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="MACOS">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">macOS is an operating system platform that MacMa operates on, designed for Apple computers.</data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <node id="CYBERCRIME">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Cybercrime encompasses illegal activities conducted via the internet, including the operations of groups like Amorfo and their banking trojans.)<|COMPLETE|></data>      <data key="d2">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </node>    <edge source="AMORFO" target="BRAZIL">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">Amorfo is a banking trojan that targets banks in Brazil</data>      <data key="d6">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </edge>    <edge source="AMORFO" target="MEXICO">      <data key="d4">8.0</data>      <data key="d5">Amorfo is a banking trojan that targets cryptocurrency services in Mexico</data>      <data key="d6">d929356f9d60bdf0033135fda6b57452</data>    </edge>    <edge source="YTY" chunk:
AT
Software description: [MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) compiled with Visual Studio that has been used by [Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) since at least 2015.(Citation: Kaspersky Ferocious Kitten Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: JHUHUGIT
Software description: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011)(Citation: CISA ICS Advisory ICSA-10-272-01)(Citation: ESET Stuxnet Under the Microscope)(Citation: Langer Stuxnet) [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was discovered in 2010, with some components being used as early as November 2008.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RemoteCMD
Software description: [RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166) is a custom tool used by [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) to execute commands on a remote system similar to SysInternal's PSEXEC functionality. (Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POORAIM
Software description: [POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) in campaigns since at least 2014. (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Saint Bot
Software description: [Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) is a .NET downloader that has been used by [Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) since at least March 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Saint Bot April 2021)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 OutSteel SaintBot February 2022 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RDAT
Software description: [RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) is a backdoor used by the suspected Iranian threat group [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). [RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) was originally identified in 2017 and targeted companies in the telecommunications sector.(Citation: Unit42 RDAT July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADNEWS
Software description: [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is malware that has been used by the actors responsible for the [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) campaign. Its name was given due to its use of RSS feeds, forums, and blogs for command and control. (Citation: Forcepoint Monsoon) (Citation: TrendMicro Patchwork Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dridex
Software description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) is a prolific banking Trojan that first appeared in 2014. By December 2019, the US Treasury estimated [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) had infected computers in hundreds of banks and financial institutions in over 40 countries, leading to more than $100 million in theft. [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) was created from the source code of the Bugat banking Trojan (also known as Cridex).(Citation: Dell Dridex Oct 2015)(Citation: Kaspersky Dridex May 2017)(Citation: Treasury EvilCorp Dec 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HALFBAKED
Software description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) is a malware family consisting of multiple components intended to establish persistence in victim networks. (Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)
Platforms: None

Software name: Sibot
Software description: [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) variants in early 2021 during its investigation of [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) and the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024).(Citation

entities.name: FEROCIOUS KITTEN
entities.description: Ferocious Kitten is a threat group that has been using the MarkiRAT malware since at least 2015.

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a cyber espionage group known for using the JHUHUGIT malware, which is based on Carberp source code.

entities.name: APT3
entities.description: APT3 is a threat group that utilizes RemoteCMD, a custom tool for executing commands on remote systems.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a threat group that has been using the POORAIM backdoor in campaigns since at least 2014.

entities.name: EMBER BEAR
entities.description: Ember Bear is a threat group that has been using the Saint Bot malware since at least March 2021.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a suspected Iranian threat group known for using the RDAT backdoor, which targets telecommunications companies.

entities.name: PATCHWORK
entities.description: Patchwork is a campaign associated with the BADNEWS malware, which uses RSS feeds and forums for command and control.

entities.name: DRIDEX
entities.description:
Dridex is a banking Trojan that has led to over $100 million in theft since its emergence in 2014.
Dridex is a prolific banking Trojan that has infected computers in hundreds of banks and financial institutions globally since 2014.

entities.name: HALFBAKED
entities.description: HALFBAKED is a malware family designed to establish persistence in victim networks.

entities.name: SIBOT
entities.description:
Sibot is dual-purpose malware that achieves persistence and downloads additional payloads, discovered during investigations of APT29.
Sibot is dual-purpose malware that achieves persistence on compromised systems and downloads additional payloads.

entities.name: JHUHUGIT
entities.description: JHUHUGIT is malware used by APT28, based on Carberp source code, serving as reconnaissance malware.

entities.name: REMOTECMD
entities.description: RemoteCMD is a custom tool used by APT3 to execute commands on remote systems.

entities.name: POORAIM
entities.description: POORAIM is a backdoor used by APT37 in campaigns since at least 2014.

entities.name: SAINT BOT
entities.description: Saint Bot is a .NET downloader used by Ember Bear since at least March 2021.

entities.name: RDAT
entities.description: RDAT is a backdoor used by the suspected Iranian threat group OilRig, identified in 2017.

entities.name: BADNEWS
entities.description: BADNEWS is malware used by the actors responsible for the Patchwork campaign, utilizing RSS feeds for command and control.

entities.name: STUXNET
entities.description: Stuxnet is the first publicly reported malware specifically targeting industrial control systems, discovered in 2010.

key="d6">76b69ad71e6d753c74907956a4f16835</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DRIDEX" target="BANKING TROJAN">      <data key="d4">18.0</data>      <data key="d5">Dridex is a banking Trojan that has infected numerous banks and financial institutions worldwide.</data>      <data key="d6">76b69ad71e6d753c74907956a4f16835</data>    </edge>    <edge source="HALFBAKED" target="MALWARE FAMILY">      <data key="d4">14.0</data>      <data key="d5">HALFBAKED is a malware family designed to establish persistence in victim networks.</data>      <data key="d6">76b69ad71e6d753c74907956a4f16835</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SIBOT" target="DUAL-PURPOSE MALWARE">      <data key="d4">2.0</data>      <data key="d5">Sibot is dual-purpose malware that achieves persistence and downloads additional payloads.</data>      <data key="d6">76b69ad71e6d753c74907956a4f16835</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

itre.org/software/S0589) is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three [Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) variants in early 2021 during its investigation of [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) and the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024).(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BONDUPDATER
Software description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). It was first observed in November 2017 during targeting of a Middle Eastern government organization, and an updated version was observed in August 2018 being used to target a government organization with spearphishing emails.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Sep 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Proton
Software description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: QuasarRAT
Software description: [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is an open-source, remote access tool that has been publicly available on GitHub since at least 2014. [QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) is developed in the C# language.(Citation: GitHub QuasarRAT)(Citation: Volexity Patchwork June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FinFisher
Software description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware reportedly sold exclusively to government agencies for use in targeted and lawful criminal investigations. It is heavily obfuscated and uses multiple anti-analysis techniques. It has other variants including [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176). (Citation: FinFisher Citation) (Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21) (Citation: FireEye FinSpy Sept 2017) (Citation: Securelist BlackOasis Oct 2017) (Citation: Microsoft FinFisher March 2018)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: NotPetya
Software description: [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) is malware that was used by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) in a worldwide attack starting on June 27, 2017. While [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) appears as a form of ransomware, its main purpose was to destroy data and disk structures on compromised systems; the attackers never intended to make the encrypted data recoverable. As such, [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) may be more appropriately thought of as a form of wiper malware. [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploits EternalBlue and EternalRomance.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: US-CERT NotPetya 2017)(Citation: ESET Telebots June 2017)(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Unit 74455 October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CSPY Downloader
Software description: [CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) is a tool designed to evade analysis and download additional payloads used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094).(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Crimson
Software description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) is a remote access Trojan that has been used by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2016.(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky Transparent Tribe August 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GRIFFON
Software description: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is a JavaScript backdoor used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046). (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Prikormka
Software description: [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) is a malware family used in a campaign known as Operation Groundbait. It has predominantly been observed in Ukraine and was used as early as 2008. (Citation: ESET Operation Groundbait)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NightClub
Software description: [NightClub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1090) is a modular implant written in C++ that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2014.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https

entities.name: FINFISHER

chunk:
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NightClub
Software description: [NightClub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1090) is a modular implant written in C++ that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2014.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004).(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HermeticWizard
Software description: [HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) is a worm that has been used to spread [HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) in attacks against organizations in Ukraine since at least 2022.(Citation: ESET Hermetic Wizard March 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ramsay
Software description: [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) is an information stealing malware framework designed to collect and exfiltrate sensitive documents, including from air-gapped systems. Researchers have identified overlaps between [Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) and the [Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012)-associated Retro malware.(Citation: Eset Ramsay May 2020)(Citation: Antiy CERT Ramsay April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Trojan.Karagany
Software description: [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) is a modular remote access tool used for recon and linked to [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035). The source code for [Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) originated from Dream Loader malware which was leaked in 2010 and sold on underground forums. (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly)(Citation: Secureworks Karagany July 2019)(Citation: Dragos DYMALLOY )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Milan
Software description: [Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015) is a backdoor implant based on [DanBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1014) that was written in Visual C++ and .NET. [Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015) has been used by [HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) since at least June 2020.(Citation: ClearSky Siamesekitten August 2021)(Citation: Kaspersky Lyceum October 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RATANKBA
Software description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) is a remote controller tool used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines. (Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA) (Citation: RATANKBA)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HELLOKITTY
Software description: [HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) is a ransomware written in C++  that shares similar code structure and functionality with [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) and [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618). [HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) has been used since at least 2020, targets have included a Polish video game developer and a Brazilian electric power company.(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Rover
Software description: [Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) is malware suspected of being used for espionage purposes. It was used in 2015 in a targeted email sent to an Indian Ambassador to Afghanistan. (Citation: Palo Alto Rover)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: T9000
Software description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, also known as Plat1. Its primary function is to gather information about the victim. It has been used in multiple targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations. (

entities.name: KE3CHANG
entities.description: Ke3chang is a group associated with the Okrum malware since its emergence in December 2016.

entities.name: HERMETICWIZARD

entities.name: HERMETICWIPER

entities.name: RAMSAY

entities.name: DARKHOTEL
entities.description: Darkhotel is a group associated with the Retro malware, which has overlaps with Ramsay.

entities.name: JRAT

entities.name: TROJAN.KARAGANY
entities.description: Trojan.Karagany is a modular remote access tool used for reconnaissance, linked to Dragonfly.

entities.name: DRAGONFLY
entities.description: Dragonfly is a group associated with the Trojan.Karagany malware.

entities.name: MILAN
entities.description: Milan is a backdoor implant based on DanBot, used by HEXANE since at least June 2020.

entities.name: HEXANE
entities.description: HEXANE is a group that has utilized the Milan backdoor implant since at least June 2020.

entities.name: RATANKBA
entities.description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group, targeting financial institutions and various organizations.

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a cybercriminal organization that has employed RATANKBA in various attacks.

entities.name: HELLOKITTY
entities.description: HELLOKITTY is a ransomware written in C++ that has been used since at least 2020, targeting specific companies.

entities.name: ROVER
entities.description: Rover is malware suspected of espionage, used in a targeted email against an Indian Ambassador to Afghanistan in 2015.

entities.name: T9000
entities.description: T9000 is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, used in targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations.

Platforms: Windows

Software name: T9000
Software description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, also known as Plat1. Its primary function is to gather information about the victim. It has been used in multiple targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations. (Citation: FireEye admin@338 March 2014) (Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GravityRAT
Software description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) is a remote access tool (RAT) and has been in ongoing development since 2016. The actor behind the tool remains unknown, but two usernames have been recovered that link to the author, which are "TheMartian" and "The Invincible." According to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FELIXROOT
Software description: [FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) is a backdoor that has been used to target Ukrainian victims. (Citation: FireEye FELIXROOT July 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RotaJakiro
Software description: [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050). First seen in 2018, it uses a plugin architecture to extend capabilities. [RotaJakiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1078) can determine it's permission level and execute according to access type (`root` or `user`).(Citation: RotaJakiro 2021 netlab360 analysis)(Citation: netlab360 rotajakiro vs oceanlotus)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: Attor
Software description: [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been seen in use since 2013. [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a loadable plugin architecture to customize functionality for specific targets.(Citation: ESET Attor Oct 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: schtasks
Software description: [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) is used to schedule execution of programs or scripts on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time. (Citation: TechNet Schtasks)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cadelspy
Software description: [Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087).(Citation: Symantec Chafer Dec 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ZxShell
Software description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) is a remote administration tool and backdoor that can be downloaded from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites. It has been used since at least 2004.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ISMInjector
Software description: [ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) is a Trojan used to install another [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) backdoor, ISMAgent. (Citation: OilRig New Delivery Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TinyZBot
Software description: [TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) is a bot written in C# that was developed by [Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: InvisiMole
Software description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) is a modular spyware program that has been used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013. [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org

entities.name: T9000
entities.description: T9000 is a backdoor malware variant used in targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations, primarily for gathering information about victims.

entities.name: GRAVITYRAT
entities.description: GravityRAT is a remote access tool that has been in development since 2016 and has been identified in attacks against organizations in India.

entities.name: FELIXROOT
entities.description: FELIXROOT is a backdoor malware that has targeted victims in Ukraine.

entities.name: ROTAJAKIRO
entities.description: RotaJakiro is a 64-bit Linux backdoor used by APT32, first seen in 2018, with a plugin architecture for extended capabilities.

entities.name: ATTOR
entities.description: Attor is a Windows-based espionage platform that has been in use since 2013, featuring a loadable plugin architecture for customization.

entities.name: SCHTASKS
entities.description: Schtasks is a Windows utility used to schedule the execution of programs or scripts at specific times.

entities.name: CADELSPY
entities.description: Cadelspy is a backdoor used by APT39.

entities.name: ZXSHELL
entities.description: ZxShell is a remote administration tool and backdoor available from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites, used since at least 2004.

entities.name: ISMINJECTOR
entities.description: ISMInjector is a Trojan that installs another backdoor, ISMAgent, used by the OilRig group.

entities.name: TINYBOT
entities.description: TinyZBot is a bot developed by Cleaver, written in C#.

entities.name: WOODY RAT
entities.description: Woody RAT is a remote access trojan used against Russian organizations since at least August 2021.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a modular malware variant primarily used as a downloader for other malware, first emerging in June 2014, targeting the banking sector.

entities.name: INVISIMOLE
entities.description: InvisiMole is a modular spyware program used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013, with backdoor modules for post-exploitation activities.

entities.name: APT39
entities.description: APT39 is a hacking group associated with the development and use of Cadelspy malware, primarily targeting entities in the Middle East.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a hacking group that utilizes ISMInjector to install backdoors on compromised systems, primarily targeting organizations in the Middle East.

entities.name: CLEAVER
entities.description: Cleaver is a hacking group known for developing the TinyZBot malware, which is used in various cyber attacks.

entities.name: INVISIMOLE GROUP
entities.description: The InvisiMole Group is known for using the InvisiMole spyware in targeted attacks against organizations in Ukraine and Russia.

[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) infrastructure has been used to download and execute [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) against a small number of victims.(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2018)(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWRUNER
Software description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server. (Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kazuar
Software description: [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework. (Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: HyperBro
Software description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) is a custom in-memory backdoor used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027).(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)(Citation: Securelist LuckyMouse June 2018)(Citation: Hacker News LuckyMouse June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Turian
Software description: [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is a backdoor that has been used by [BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) to target Ministries of Foreign Affairs, telecommunication companies, and charities in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. First reported in 2021, [Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) is likely related to Quarian, an older backdoor that was last observed being used in 2013 against diplomatic targets in Syria and the United States.(Citation: ESET BackdoorDiplomacy Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: SharpStage
Software description: [SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.(Citation: Cybereason Molerats Dec 2020)(Citation: BleepingComputer Molerats Dec 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: REvil
Software description: [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) is a ransomware family that has been linked to the [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) group and operated as ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) since at least April 2019. [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496), which as been used against organizations in the manufacturing, transportation, and electric sectors, is highly configurable and shares code similarities with the GandCrab RaaS.(Citation: Secureworks REvil September 2019)(Citation: Intel 471 REvil March 2020)(Citation: Group IB Ransomware May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Black Basta
Software description: [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) is ransomware written in C++ that has been offered within the ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model since at least April 2022; there are variants that target Windows and VMWare ESXi servers. [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) operations have included the double extortion technique where in addition to demanding ransom for decrypting the files of targeted organizations the cyber actors also threaten to post sensitive information to a leak site if the ransom is not paid. [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) affiliates have targeted multiple high-value organizations, with the largest number of victims based in the U.S. Based on similarities in TTPs, leak sites, payment sites, and negotiation tactics, security researchers assess the [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) RaaS operators could include current or former members of the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) group.(Citation: Palo Alto Networks Black Basta August 2022)(Citation: Deep Instinct Black Basta August 2022)(Citation: Minerva Labs Black Basta May 2022)(Citation: Avertium Black Basta June 2022)(Citation: NCC Group Black Basta June 2022)(Citation: Cyble Black Basta May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: INVISIMOLE GROUP
entities.description: The InvisiMole Group is a cybercriminal organization known for using the InvisiMole spyware program since at least 2013, targeting victims primarily in Ukraine and Russia.

entities.name: GAMAREDON GROUP
entities.description: The Gamaredon Group is a cybercriminal organization that has been associated with the infrastructure used to download and execute InvisiMole against victims.

entities.name: UKRAINE
entities.description: Ukraine is a country where victims of the InvisiMole spyware have been compromised.

entities.name: RUSSIA
entities.description: Russia is another country where victims of the InvisiMole spyware have been compromised.

entities.name: VALAK
entities.description: Valak is a multi-stage modular malware that functions as an information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.

entities.name: POWRUNER
entities.description: POWRUNER is a PowerShell script used for sending and receiving commands to and from a command and control server.

entities.name: KAZUAR
entities.description: Kazuar is a multi-platform backdoor Trojan written in the Microsoft .NET framework, capable of functioning across various operating systems.

entities.name: HYPERBRO
entities.description: HyperBro is a custom in-memory backdoor used by Threat Group-3390 for cyber operations.

entities.name: TURIAN
entities.description: Turian is a backdoor used by BackdoorDiplomacy to target various sectors including Ministries of Foreign Affairs and telecommunications.

entities.name: SHARPASTAGE
entities.description: SharpStage is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities, used in various cyber attacks.

entities.name: REVIL
entities.description: REvil is a ransomware family linked to the GOLD SOUTHFIELD group, operating as ransomware-as-a-service since at least April 2019.

entities.name: BLACK BASTA
entities.description: Black Basta is a ransomware written in C++ that operates under the ransomware-as-a-service model, known for double extortion tactics.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that is targeted by various malware programs including InvisiMole, Valak, POWRUNER, Kazuar, HyperBro, SharpStage, REvil, and Black Basta.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that is targeted by the Turian malware program.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that is targeted by the Kazuar malware program.

Software name: IceApple
Software description: [IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) is a modular Internet Information Services (IIS) post-exploitation framework, that has been used since at least 2021 against the technology, academic, and government sectors.(Citation: CrowdStrike IceApple May 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WannaCry
Software description: [WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) is ransomware that was first seen in a global attack during May 2017, which affected more than 150 countries. It contains worm-like features to spread itself across a computer network using the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue.(Citation: LogRhythm WannaCry)(Citation: US-CERT WannaCry 2017)(Citation: Washington Post WannaCry 2017)(Citation: FireEye WannaCry 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064).(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Flame
Software description: [Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) is a sophisticated toolkit that has been used to collect information since at least 2010, largely targeting Middle East countries. (Citation: Kaspersky Flame)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Socksbot
Software description: [Socksbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0273) is a backdoor that  abuses Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies. (Citation: TrendMicro Patchwork Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GrimAgent
Software description: [GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) is a backdoor that has been used before the deployment of [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) ransomware since at least 2020; it is likely used by [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) and [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102).(Citation: Group IB GrimAgent July 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DEATHRANSOM
Software description: [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) is ransomware written in C that has been used since at least 2020, and has potential overlap with [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) and [HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617).(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Mispadu
Software description: [Mispadu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1122) is a banking trojan written in Delphi that was first observed in 2019 and uses a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) business model.(Citation: ESET Security Mispadu Facebook Ads 2019)(Citation: SCILabs Malteiro 2021) This malware is operated, managed, and sold by the [Malteiro](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1026) cybercriminal group.(Citation: SCILabs Malteiro 2021) [Mispadu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1122) has mainly been used to target victims in Brazil and Mexico, and has also had confirmed operations throughout Latin America and Europe.(Citation: SCILabs Malteiro 2021)(Citation: SCILabs URSA/Mispadu Evolution 2023)(Citation: Segurança Informática URSA Sophisticated Loader 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BLUELIGHT
Software description: [BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) is a remote access Trojan used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that was first observed in early 2021.(Citation: Volexity InkySquid BLUELIGHT August 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CozyCar
Software description: [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. It is a modular malware platform, and its backdoor component can be instructed to download and execute a variety of modules with different functionality. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Helminth
Software description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170

entities.name: BLACK BASTA
entities.description: Black Basta is a cybercriminal group known for its ransomware attacks and has been active since at least 2022.

entities.name: ICEAPPLE
entities.description: IceApple is a modular Internet Information Services (IIS) post-exploitation framework used against technology, academic, and government sectors since at least 2021.

entities.name: WANACRY
entities.description: WannaCry is ransomware that first appeared in May 2017, affecting over 150 countries and utilizing the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue to spread.

entities.name: STONEDRILL
entities.description: StoneDrill is wiper malware associated with APT33, targeting Middle Eastern and European entities.

entities.name: FLAME
entities.description: Flame is a sophisticated toolkit used for information collection, primarily targeting countries in the Middle East since at least 2010.

entities.name: SOCKSBOT
entities.description: Socksbot is a backdoor that exploits Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies.

entities.name: GRIMAGENT
entities.description: GrimAgent is a backdoor used prior to the deployment of Ryuk ransomware, likely operated by FIN6 and Wizard Spider since at least 2020.

entities.name: DEATHRANSOM
entities.description: DEATHRANSOM is ransomware written in C, used since at least 2020, with potential overlaps with other ransomware families.

entities.name: MISPADU
entities.description: Mispadu is a banking trojan that operates on a Malware-as-a-Service model, targeting victims primarily in Brazil and Mexico since 2019.

entities.name: BLUELIGHT
entities.description: BLUELIGHT is a remote access Trojan used by APT37, first observed in early 2021.

entities.name: REVENGE RAT
entities.description: Revenge RAT is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET, used for unauthorized access to systems.

entities.name: COZYCAR
entities.description: CozyCar is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, featuring a modular platform for various malicious functionalities.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a cyber threat group that has been linked to the development and deployment of the BLUELIGHT remote access Trojan.

entities.name: FIN6
entities.description: FIN6 is a cybercriminal group known for its ransomware operations and is likely associated with the use of GrimAgent malware.

entities.name: WIZARD SPIDER
entities.description: Wizard Spider is a cybercriminal group that has been linked to various ransomware attacks and is associated with the use of GrimAgent.

entities.name: MALTEIRO
entities.description: Malteiro is a cybercriminal group that operates the Mispadu banking trojan, targeting victims primarily in Latin America.

key="d1">Black Basta is a cybercriminal group known for its ransomware attacks and has been active since at least 2022.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="ICEAPPLE">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">IceApple is a modular Internet Information Services (IIS) post-exploitation framework used against technology, academic, and government sectors since at least 2021.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="WANACRY">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">WannaCry is ransomware that first appeared in May 2017, affecting over 150 countries and utilizing the SMBv1 exploit EternalBlue to spread.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="STONEDRILL">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">StoneDrill is wiper malware associated with APT33, targeting Middle Eastern and European entities.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="FLAME">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">Flame is a sophisticated toolkit used for information collection, primarily targeting countries in the Middle East since at least 2010.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="SOCKSBOT">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">Socksbot is a backdoor that exploits Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="GRIMAGENT">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">GrimAgent is a backdoor used prior to the deployment of Ryuk ransomware, likely operated by FIN6 and Wizard Spider since at least 2020.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="DEATHRANSOM">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">DEATHRANSOM is ransomware written in C, used since at least 2020, with potential overlaps with other ransomware families.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="MISPADU">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">Mispadu is a banking trojan that operates on a Malware-as-a-Service model, targeting victims primarily in Brazil and Mexico since 2019.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="BLUELIGHT">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">BLUELIGHT is a remote access Trojan used by APT37, first observed in early 2021.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="REVENGE RAT">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">Revenge RAT is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET, used for unauthorized access to systems.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="COZYCAR">      <data key="d0">SOFTWARE</data>      <data key="d1">CozyCar is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, featuring a modular platform for various malicious functionalities.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="APT37">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">APT37 is a cyber threat group that has been linked to the development and deployment of the BLUELIGHT remote access Trojan.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="FIN6">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">FIN6 is a cybercriminal group known for its ransomware operations and is likely associated with the use of GrimAgent malware.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="WIZARD SPIDER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Wizard Spider is a cybercriminal group that has been linked to various ransomware attacks and is associated with the use of GrimAgent.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="MALTEIRO">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Malteiro is a cybercriminal group that operates the Mispadu banking trojan, targeting victims primarily in Latin America.</data>      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <node id="APT33">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </node>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="ICEAPPLE">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Black Basta has utilized IceApple in its cyber operations against various sectors.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="WANACRY">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">Black Basta's activities are part of the broader ransomware landscape that includes WannaCry.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="STONEDRILL">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">Black Basta is associated with various malware including StoneDrill in its cybercriminal activities.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="GRIMAGENT">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Black Basta's operations may overlap with those of GrimAgent, which is used by similar threat actors.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="MISPADU">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Mispadu is a banking trojan that may be used in conjunction with Black Basta's operations targeting financial sectors.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="FLAME">      <data key="d3">3.0</data>      <data key="d4">Flame's sophisticated toolkit may be leveraged by groups like Black Basta for targeted attacks.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="DEATHRANSOM">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">DEATHRANSOM is another ransomware variant that could be part of Black Basta's arsenal.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLACK BASTA" target="BLUELIGHT">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">BLUELIGHT is a remote access tool that could be used by Black Basta for initial access in their attacks.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WANACRY" target="GRIMAGENT">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both WannaCry and GrimAgent are part of the ransomware ecosystem, often used in similar attack vectors.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="STONEDRILL" target="APT33">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">APT33 is the group associated with the development and deployment of StoneDrill malware in cyber attacks.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRIMAGENT" target="FIN6">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">FIN6 is likely the operator of GrimAgent, which is used before deploying ransomware like Ryuk.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="GRIMAGENT" target="WIZARD SPIDER">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Wizard Spider is associated with the use of GrimAgent in its ransomware operations.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="MISPADU" target="MALTEIRO">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Malteiro operates the Mispadu banking trojan, which is part of its cybercriminal activities targeting financial sectors.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BLUELIGHT" target="APT37">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">APT37 is the group that has been observed using the BLUELIGHT remote access Trojan in its operations.</data>      <data key="d5">95cf04f6129fa295072667edb418b098</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
0046) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. It is a modular malware platform, and its backdoor component can be instructed to download and execute a variety of modules with different functionality. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Helminth
Software description: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) is a backdoor that has at least two variants - one written in VBScript and PowerShell that is delivered via a macros in Excel spreadsheets, and one that is a standalone Windows executable. (Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TrickBot
Software description: [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) is a Trojan spyware program written in C++ that first emerged in September 2016 as a possible successor to [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024). [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) was developed and initially used by [Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) for targeting banking sites in North America, Australia, and throughout Europe; it has since been used against all sectors worldwide as part of "big game hunting" ransomware campaigns.(Citation: S2 Grupo TrickBot June 2017)(Citation: Fidelis TrickBot Oct 2016)(Citation: IBM TrickBot Nov 2016)(Citation: CrowdStrike Wizard Spider October 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: iKitten
Software description: [iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) is a macOS exfiltration agent  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: SharpDisco
Software description: [SharpDisco](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1089) is a dropper developed in C# that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2020 to load malicious plugins.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WindTail
Software description: [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) is a macOS surveillance implant used by [Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112). [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) shares code similarities with Hack Back aka KitM OSX.(Citation: SANS Windshift August 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail1 dec 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail2 jan 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BlackEnergy
Software description: [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3. (Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TajMahal
Software description: [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is a multifunctional spying framework that has been in use since at least 2014. [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is comprised of two separate packages, named Tokyo and Yokohama, and can deploy up to 80 plugins.(Citation: Kaspersky TajMahal April 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: metaMain
Software description: [metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) is a backdoor used by [Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013) to maintain long-term access to compromised machines; it has also been used to decrypt [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) into memory.(Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Sept 2022)(Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Technical Appendix Sept 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: LookBack
Software description: [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) is a remote access trojan written in C++ that was used against at least three US utility companies in July 2019. The TALONITE activity group has been observed using [LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582).(Citation: Proofpoint LookBack Malware Aug 2019)(Citation: Dragos TALONITE)(Citation: Dragos Threat Report 2020)
Platforms: Windows

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber threat group known for its sophisticated cyber espionage activities, particularly targeting government and private sector organizations from 2010 to 2015.

entities.name: HELMINTH
entities.description: Helminth is a backdoor malware with at least two variants, designed to be delivered via macros in Excel spreadsheets or as a standalone Windows executable.

entities.name: TRICKBOT
entities.description: TrickBot is a Trojan spyware program that emerged in 2016, initially targeting banking sites and has since evolved to attack various sectors globally.

entities.name: IKITTEN
entities.description: iKitten is a macOS exfiltration agent used for data theft.

entities.name: SHARPDISCO
entities.description: SharpDisco is a dropper developed in C# used by MoustachedBouncer to load malicious plugins since at least 2020.

entities.name: WINDTAIL
entities.description: WindTail is a macOS surveillance implant used by Windshift, sharing code similarities with other malware.

entities.name: POWERSPOILT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open-source offensive security framework that includes various PowerShell modules for penetration testing.

entities.name: BLACKENERGY
entities.description: BlackEnergy is a malware toolkit used for creating botnets and conducting DDoS attacks, known for its use in geopolitical conflicts.

entities.name: TAJMAHAL
entities.description: TajMahal is a multifunctional spying framework that has been in use since at least 2014, capable of deploying numerous plugins.

entities.name: METAMAIN
entities.description: metaMain is a backdoor used by Metador for maintaining long-term access to compromised systems.

entities.name: LOOKBACK
entities.description: LookBack is a remote access trojan that targeted US utility companies in 2019, associated with the TALONITE activity group.

entities.name: WINDSHIFT
entities.description: Windshift is a cyber threat group that uses WindTail for surveillance and data exfiltration activities.
